title: Mum diagnosed with terminal cancer - after she is picked at random for screening trial - Manchester Evening News
text:

A fitness fanatic mum discovered she had terminal cancer by sheer chance - after being picked at random to take part in a breast screening trial. 
Sandra Dickinson received a letter asking her to take part in an NHS trial which offered breast screening to women under 50. 
The scan in August 2015 revealed a lump in her breast, and the mum-of-two from Cadishead, Salford , was referred to Wythenshawe Hospital where doctors told her the devastating news that it was cancer. 
Sandra was just 48 at the time and normally wouldn’t have been invited for a mammogram for another two years. Sandra with husband Ron (Photo: UGC) Read More Christie patient left with no trace of cancer after taking part in world first drug trial 
Her daughter Melissa Cullen said never in a million years did they expect their healthy, fitness fanatic mum to be diagnosed with the disease from a random trial. 
She said that straight away Sandra underwent surgery to remove two lumps from her breast as well as the lymphnodes from her arm, and began on hormone therapy. 
But the treatment didn’t work, the cancer continued to spread to her bones, and she ended up with tumours on her spine and pelvis. 
“We just couldn’t believe how it had rapidly spread over such a small amount of time. It was so hard for us to pick ourselves up and be positive after all the bad news. Sandra with her dog Bobby who went to visit her in hospital (Photo: UGC) Read More Mum of tragic Louis Simpson urges people to support Salford mum's cancer fight in his memory 
“The doctors went on to try chemotherapy tablets, three lots of radiotherapy to help manage the tumours and pain, which unfortunately didn’t stop it from spreading. 
“In October 2016, the doctor decided they were going to try introvenus chemotherapy, and if that failed too, mum would have just six months to live. 
“We were devastated.” 
Last month, Sandra, now 49, and her family were told the news they’d been dreading – she wasn’t responding to treatment, the cancer was spreading, her tumours were growing, and there was little more that could be done. Sandra pictured with her family at Christmas (Photo: UGC) Read More Meet the husband-and-wife scientists whose cancer breakthrough could save thousands of lives 
Melissa, 23, her brother Ben, 20, and stepdad Ron, 59, refused to accept this and immediately began researching alternative treatments and discovered a clinic in London that offered a form of potentially life-saving immunotherapy, but at a cost of more than £6,000 per treatment. 
A GoFundMe page was set up to try and help towards the cost, and so far enough has been raised for an initial consultation, as well as the first treatment. 
Melissa is now appealing for help to raise more to give Sandra the best chance possible. 
“My mum is a really special person, she is very social, likes going out with her friends, she goes to church, loves baking cakes and she’s always doing something to raise money for charity. Read More 
“During her battle with cancer she has raised more than £4,000 for cancer charities. 
“Mum is always helping others and I wanted to try and help her by giving something back. 
“This might be able to save her life and I know she would never be able to thank you all enough for that.” 
To donate to Sandra’s appeal, visit HERE . 
Breast screening is currently offered to women aged 50-70 in England. However, the NHS is in the process of extending the programme as a trial, offering screening to some women aged 47-73. Like us on Facebook
